We are proud to announce a new partnership with Cincinnati Children's to provide families access to private mental health support services for students as part of our district's commitment to ensuring that each learner feels emotionally and physically safe. This year, we will have school-based mental health therapists in ALL of our schools - and they are ready to support in-person learners and online learners.

The partnership with Cincinnati Children’s and their services do not require any financial support from the district. Students and families needing services can cover therapy visits through private insurance, Medicaid, or private pay options. Assistance may be available for families experiencing financial difficulty.

Parents and school guidance counselors can make student referrals for service. Students can also self-refer for services. Ultimately, the decision to move forward with therapeutic services is up to the family.

post_text: The Class of 1960 loved touring Mason Central (their school for grades 1-11) and checking out how much their high school (today’s MMS) has changed. They were so pleased with how well their school has been taken care of and loved over the years. They were the first class to graduate from the “new” Mason High School - though it’s footprint was much different in 1960 and they still played basketball and graduated in the Mason Central Gym. Their beloved teacher (who became a well-respected Mason Principal when he was just 28) the 91-year old Mr. Emerson Brown came along and regaled everyone with stories. This class’s motto was “First to leave, last to forget.” We are so grateful that they never forget how Mason shaped their lives!💚

Quinn is a star on the school's competitive jump rope team, the Comet Skippers, an active member of SIBS and NHS, and one of the founding members of the school's Hope Squad. She and her classmates are encouraging community members to attend a special event on February 27 with Kate Fagan, New York Times best-selling author of What Made Maddy Run, who will share how achievement culture affects teens, as well as the need to increase communication on the transition from high school to college.

"We talk a lot about not being afraid to straight up ask people 'Are you thinking about suicide?'"

Part of our #CometCulture calls on us to “Own the Moment” by doing the right thing, especially when it is hard. On March 17, 2020 Mason City Schools will be on the ballot with a critical operating levy. Mason has not received new operating levy funds in 15 years. The revenue we are asking voters for is needed to maintain the Mason Quality that exists today. If we fail, this will be the second consecutive levy failure in a decade and our quality and reputation will change.

Please watch this video to learn more about the specific cost structure changes and program reductions should the levy fail.

This week's #YourStoryMatters podcast features MHS Child Nutrition Kitchen Manager Sarah Burkhart. Not only does she oversee making sure that 3500 high school students are fed lunch in an hour and half - but she has a gift for really seeing people, and being there for kids who need someone in their corner. Sarah is a biracial single mom of three Mason Comets, and serves on the school's Inclusive Excellence Team.

“Being a biracial person in Cincinnati, and having my foot in both worlds, was a difficult straddle.”

post_text: #FinancialFactFriday Some people have asked if Ohio offers property tax relief for senior citizens. The answer is yes! Qualifying, low-income senior citizens, permanently and totally disabled Ohioans, and others who receive the homestead exemption tax credit can exempt up to $25,000 of the market value of their homes from all property taxes. Visit the Ohio Department of Taxation’s website to learn more about the homestead exemption.
